Source Code for Module ivs.sed.builder

   1  # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- 
   2  """ 
   3  SED builder program. 
   4   
   5  To construct an SED, use the SED class. The functions defined in this module 
   6  are mainly convenience functions specifically for that class, but can be used 
   7  outside of the SED class if you know what you're doing. 
   8   
   9  Table of contents: 
  10       
  11      1. Retrieving and plotting photometry of a target 
  12      2. Where/what is my target? 
  13      3. SED fitting using a grid based approach 
  14          - Saving SED fits 
  15          - Loading SED fits 
  16      4. Accessing the best fitting full SED model 
  17      5. Radii, distances and luminosities 
  18          - Relations between quantities 
  19          - Parallaxes 
  20          - Seismic constraints 
  21          - Reddening constraints 
  22          - Evolutionary constraints 
  23   
  24  Section 1. Retrieving and plotting photometry of a target 
  25  ========================================================= 
  26   
  27  >>> mysed = SED('HD180642') 
  28  >>> mysed.get_photometry() 
  29  >>> mysed.plot_data() 
  30   
  31  and call Pylab's C{show} function to show to the screen: 
  32   
  33  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_example_photometry.png] 
  34   
  35  Catch IndexErrors and TypeErrors in case no photometry is found. 
  36   
  37  You can give a B{search radius} to C{get_photometry} via the keyword C{radius}. 
  38  The default value is 10 arcseconds for stars dimmer than 6th magnitude, and 60 
  39  arcseconds for brighter stars. The best value of course depends on the density 
  40  of the field. 
  41   
  42  >>> mysed.get_photometry(radius=5.) 
  43   
  44  If your star's name is not recognised by any catalog, you can give coordinates 
  45  to look for photometry. In that case, the ID of the star given in the C{SED} 
  46  command will not be used to search photometry (only to save the phot file): 
  47   
  48  >>> mysed.get_photometry(ra=289.31167983,dec=1.05941685) 
  49   
  50  Note that C{ra} and C{dec} are given in B{degrees}. 
  51   
  52  You best B{switch on the logger} (see L{ivs.aux.loggers.get_basic_logger}) to see the progress: 
  53  sometimes, access to catalogs can take a long time (the GATOR sources are 
  54  typically slow). If one of the C{gator}, C{vizier} or C{gcpd} is impossibly slow 
  55  or the site is down, you can B{include/exclude these sources} via the keywords 
  56  C{include} or C{exclude}, which take a list of strings (choose from C{gator}, 
  57  C{vizier} and/or C{gcpd}). For ViZieR, there is an extra option to change to 
  58  another mirror site via 
  59   
  60  >>> vizier.change_mirror() 
  61   
  62  The L{vizier.change_mirror} function cycles through all the mirrors continuously, 
  63  so sooner or later you will end up with the default one and repeat the cycle. 
  64   
  65  >>> mysed.get_photometry(exclude=['gator']) 
  66   
  67  The results will be written to the file B{HD180642.phot}. An example content is:: 
  68

 131   
 132  Once a .phot file is written and L{get_photometry} is called again for the same 
 133  target, the script will B{not retrieve the photometry from the internet again}, 
 134  but will use the contents of the file instead. The purpose is minimizing network 
 135  traffic and maximizing speed. If you want to refresh the search, simply manually 
 136  delete the .phot file or set C{force=True} when calling L{get_photometry}.  
 137   
 138  The content of the .phot file is most easily read using the L{ivs.io.ascii.read2recarray} 
 139  function. Be careful, as it contains both absolute fluxes as flux ratios. 
 140   
 141  >>> data = ascii.read2recarray('HD180642.phot') 
 142   
 143  Notice that in the C{.phot} files, also a C{comment} column is added. You can  
 144  find translation of some of the flags here (i.e. upper limit, extended source etc..), 
 145  or sometimes just additional remarks on variability etc. Not all catalogs have 
 146  this feature implemented, so you are still responsible yourself for checking 
 147  the quality of the photometry. 
 148   
 149  The references to each source are given in the C{bibtex} column. Simply call 
 150   
 151  >>> mysed.save_bibtex() 
 152   
 153  to convert those bibcodes to a C{.bib} file. 
 154   
 155  Using L{SED.plot_MW_side} and L{SED.plot_MW_top}, you can make a picture of where 
 156  your star is located with respect to the Milky Way and the Sun. With L{SED.plot_finderchart}, 
 157  you can check the location of your photometry, and also see if proper motions 
 158  etc are available. 
 159   
 160  Section 2. Where/what is my target? 
 161  =================================== 
 162   
 163  To give you some visual information on the target, the following plotting 
 164  procedure might be of some help. 
 165   
 166  To check whether the downloaded photometry is really belonging to the target, 
 167  instead of some neighbouring star (don't forget to set C{radius} when looking 
 168  for photometry!), you can generate a finderchart with the location of the 
 169  downloaded photometry overplotted. On top of that, proper motion data is added 
 170  when available, as well as radial velocity data. When a distance is available, 
 171  the proper motion velocity will be converted to a true tangential velocity. 
 172   
 173  >>> p = pl.figure();mysed.plot_finderchart(window_size=1) 
 174   
 175  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_finderchart.png] 
 176   
 177  To know the location of your target wrt the Milky Way (assuming your target is 
 178  in the milky way), you can call 
 179   
 180  >>> p = pl.figure();mysed.plot_MW_side() 
 181  >>> p = pl.figure();mysed.plot_MW_top() 
 182   
 183  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_MWside.png] 
 184   
 185  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_MWtop.png] 
 186   
 187  Section 3. SED fitting using a grid based approach 
 188  ================================================== 
 189   
 190  Subsection 3.1 Single star 
 191  -------------------------- 
 192   
 193  We make an SED of HD180642 by simply B{exploring a whole grid of Kurucz models} 
 194  (constructed via L{fit.generate_grid}, iterated over via L{fit.igrid_search} and 
 195  evaluated with L{fit.stat_chi2}). The model with the best parameters is picked 
 196  out and we make a full SED with those parameters. 
 197   
 198  >>> mysed = SED('HD180642') 
 199  >>> mysed.get_photometry() 
 200   
 201  Now we have collected B{all fluxes and colors}, but we do not want to use them 
 202  all: first, B{fluxes and colors are not independent}, so you probably want to use 
 203  either only absolute fluxes or only colors (plus perhaps one absolute flux per 
 204  system to compute the angular diameter) (see L{SED.set_photometry_scheme}). Second, 
 205  B{some photometry is better suited for fitting an SED than others}; typically IR 
 206  photometry does not add much to the fitting of massive stars, or it can be 
 207  contaminated with circumstellar material. Third, B{some photometry is not so 
 208  reliable}, i.e. the measurements can have large systematic uncertainties due to 
 209  e.g. calibration effects, which are typically not included in the error bars. 
 210   
 211  Currently, four standard schemes are implemented, which you can set via L{SED.set_photometry_scheme}: 
 212   
 213      1. C{absolute}: use only absolute values 
 214      2. C{colors}: use only colors (no angular diameter values calculated) 
 215      3. C{combo}: use all colors and one absolute value per photometric system 
 216      4. C{irfm}: (infrared flux method) use colors for wavelengths shorter than 
 217      infrared wavelengths, and absolute values for systems in the infrared. The 
 218      infrared is defined as wavelength longer than 1 micron, but this can be 
 219      customized with the keyword C{infrared=(value,unit)} in 
 220      L{SED.set_photometry_scheme}. 
 221   
 222  Here, we chose to use colors and one absolute flux per system, but exclude IR 
 223  photometry (wavelength range above 2.5 micron), and some systems and colors which 
 224  we know are not so trustworthy: 
 225   
 226  >>> mysed.set_photometry_scheme('combo') 
 227  >>> mysed.exclude(names=['STROMGREN.HBN-HBW','USNOB1','SDSS','DENIS','COUSINS','ANS','TD1'],wrange=(2.5e4,1e10)) 
 228   
 229  You can L{include}/L{exclude} photoemtry based on name, wavelength range, source and index, 
 230  and only select absolute photometry or colors (L{include_abs},L{include_colors}). 
 231  When working in interactive mode, in particular the index is useful. Print the 
 232  current set of photometry to the screen with  
 233   
 234  >>> print(photometry2str(mysed.master,color=True,index=True)) 
 235   
 236  and you will see in green the included photometry, and in red the excluded photometry. 
 237  You will see that each column is preceded by an index, you can use these indices 
 238  to select/deselect the photometry. 
 239   
 240  Speed up the fitting process by copying the model grids to the scratch disk 
 241   
 242  >>> model.copy2scratch(z='*') 
 243   
 244  Start the grid based fitting process and show some plots. We use 100000 randomly 
 245  distributed points over the grid: 
 246   
 247  >>> mysed.igrid_search(points=100000) 
 248   
 249  Delete the model grids from the scratch disk 
 250   
 251  >>> model.clean_scratch() 
 252   
 253  and make the plot 
 254   
 255  >>> p = pl.figure() 
 256  >>> p = pl.subplot(131);mysed.plot_sed() 
 257  >>> p = pl.subplot(132);mysed.plot_grid(limit=None) 
 258  >>> p = pl.subplot(133);mysed.plot_grid(x='ebv',y='z',limit=None) 
 259   
 260  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_example_fitting01.png] 
 261   
 262  The grid is a bit too coarse for our liking around the minimum, so we zoom in on 
 263  the results: 
 264   
 265  >>> teffrange = mysed.results['igrid_search']['CI']['teffL'],mysed.results['igrid_search']['CI']['teffU'] 
 266  >>> loggrange = mysed.results['igrid_search']['CI']['loggL'],mysed.results['igrid_search']['CI']['loggU'] 
 267  >>> ebvrange = mysed.results['igrid_search']['CI']['ebvL'],mysed.results['igrid_search']['CI']['ebvU'] 
 268  >>> mysed.igrid_search(points=100000,teffrange=teffrange,loggrange=loggrange,ebvrange=ebvrange) 
 269   
 270  and repeat the plot 
 271   
 272  >>> p = pl.figure() 
 273  >>> p = pl.subplot(131);mysed.plot_sed(plot_deredded=True) 
 274  >>> p = pl.subplot(132);mysed.plot_grid(limit=None) 
 275  >>> p = pl.subplot(133);mysed.plot_grid(x='ebv',y='z',limit=None) 
 276   
 277  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_example_fitting02.png] 
 278   
 279  You can automatically make plots of (most plotting functions take C{colors=True/False} 
 280  as an argument so you can make e.g. the 'color' SED and 'absolute value' SED): 
 281   
 282      1. the grid (see L{SED.plot_grid}) 
 283      2. the SED (see L{SED.plot_sed})  
 284      3. the fit statistics (see L{SED.plot_chi2}) 
 285       
 286  To change the grid, load the L{ivs.sed.model} module and call 
 287  L{ivs.sed.model.set_defaults} with appropriate arguments. See that module for 
 288  conventions on the grid structure when adding custom grids. 
 289   
 290  To add arrays manually, i.e. not from the predefined set of internet catalogs, 
 291  use the L{SED.add_photometry_fromarrays} function. 
 292   
 293  B{Warning}: Be careful when interpreting the Chi2 results. In order to always have a 
 294  solution, the chi2 is rescaled so that the minimum equals 1, in the case the 
 295  probability of the best chi2-model is zero. The Chi2 rescaling factor I{f} mimicks 
 296  a rescaling of all errorbars with a factor I{sqrt(f)}, and does not discriminate 
 297  between systems (i.e., B{all} errors are blown up). If the errorbars are 
 298  underestimated, it could be that the rescaling factor is also wrong, which means 
 299  that the true probability region can be larger or smaller! 
 300   
 301  Subsection 3.2 Binary star  
 302  -------------------------- 
 303   
 304  The SED class can create SEDs for multiple stars as well. There are 2 options  
 305  available, the multiple SED fit which in theory can handle any number of stars, 
 306  and the binary SED fit which is for binaries only, and uses the mass of both  
 307  components to restrict the radii when combining two model SEDs. 
 308   
 309  As an example we take the system PG1104+243, which consists of a subdwarf B star, 
 310  and a G2 type mainsequence star. The photometry from the standard catalogues that 
 311  are build in this class, is of to low quality, so we use photometry obtained from  
 312  U{the subdwarf database<http://catserver.ing.iac.es/sddb/>}. 
 313   
 314  >>> mysed = SED('PG1104+243') 
 315   
 316  >>> meas, e_meas, units, photbands, source = ascii.read2array('pg1104+243_sddb.phot', dtype=str) 
 317  >>> meas = np.array(meas, dtype=float) 
 318  >>> e_meas = np.array(e_meas, dtype=float) 
 319  >>> mysed.add_photometry_fromarrays(meas, e_meas, units, photbands, source) 
 320   
 321  We use only the absolute fluxes 
 322   
 323  >>> mysed.set_photometry_scheme('abs') 
 324   
 325  For the main sequence component we use kurucz models with solar metalicity, and 
 326  for the sdB component tmap models. And we copy the model grids to the scratch disk 
 327  to speed up the process: 
 328   
 329  >>> grid1 = dict(grid='kurucz',z=+0.0) 
 330  >>> grid2 = dict(grid='tmap') 
 331  >>> model.set_defaults_multiple(grid1,grid2) 
 332  >>> model.copy2scratch() 
 333   
 334  The actual fitting. The second fit starts from the 95% probability intervals of 
 335  the first fit. 
 336   
 337  >>> teff_ms = (5000,7000) 
 338  >>> teff_sdb = (25000,45000) 
 339  >>> logg_ms = (4.00,4.50) 
 340  >>> logg_sdb = (5.00,6.50) 
 341  >>> mysed.igrid_search(masses=(0.47,0.71) ,teffrange=(teff_ms,teff_fix),loggrange=(logg_ms,logg_sdb), ebvrange=(0.00,0.02), zrange=(0,0), points=2000000, type='binary') 
 342  >>> mysed.igrid_search(masses=(0.47,0.71) ,points=2000000, type='binary') 
 343   
 344  Delete the used models from the scratch disk 
 345   
 346  >>> model.clean_scratch() 
 347   
 348  Plot the results 
 349   
 350  >>> p = pl.figure() 
 351  >>> p = pl.subplot(131); mysed.plot_sed(plot_deredded=False) 
 352  >>> p = pl.subplot(132); mysed.plot_grid(x='teff', y='logg', limit=0.95) 
 353  >>> p = pl.subplot(133); mysed.plot_grid(x='teff-2', y='logg-2', limit=0.95) 
 354   
 355  ]]include figure]]ivs_sed_builder_example_fittingPG1104+243.png] 
 356   
 357  Subsection 3.3 Saving SED fits 
 358  ------------------------------ 
 359

 362  >>> mysed.save_fits()

 451   
 452  Subsection 3.4 Loading SED fits 
 453  ------------------------------- 
 454   
 455  Once saved, you can load the contents of the FITS file again into an SED object 
 456  via 
 457   
 458  >>> mysed = SED('HD180642') 
 459  >>> mysed.load_fits() 
 460   
 461  and then you can build all the plots again easily. You can of course use the 
 462  predefined plotting scripts to start a plot, and then later on change the 
 463  properties of the labels, legends etc... for higher quality plots or to better 
 464  suit your needs. 
 465   
 466  Section 4. Accessing the best fitting full SED model 
 467  ==================================================== 
 468   
 469  You can access the full SED model that matches the parameters found by the 
 470  fitting routine via: 
 471   
 472  >>> wavelength,flux,deredded_flux = mysed.get_best_model() 
 473   
 474  Note that this model is retrieved after fitting, and was not in any way used 
 475  during the fitting. As a consequence, there could be small differences between 
 476  synthetic photometry calculated from this returned model and the synthetic 
 477  fluxes stored in C{mysed.results['igrid_search']['synflux']}, which is the 
 478  synthetic photometry coming from the interpolation of the grid of pre-interpolated 
 479  photometry. See the documentation of L{SED.get_model} for more information. 
 480   
 481  Section 5. Radii, distances and luminosities 
 482  ============================================ 
 483   
 484  Subsection 4.1. Relations between quantities 
 485  -------------------------------------------- 
 486   
 487  Most SED grids don't have the radius as a tunable model parameter. The scale 
 488  factor, which is available for all fitted models in the grid when at least one 
 489  absolute photometric point is included, is directly propertional to the angular 
 490  diameter. The following relations hold:: 
 491   
 492      >> distance = radius / np.sqrt(scale) 
 493      >> radius = distance * np.sqrt(scale) 
 494   
 495  Where C{radius} and C{distance} have equal units. The true absolute luminosity 
 496  (solar units) is related to the absolute luminosity from the SED (solar units) 
 497  via the radius (solar units):: 
 498       
 499      >> L_abs_true = L_abs * radius**2 
 500   
 501  Finally, the angular diameter can be computed via:: 
 502   
 503      >> 2*conversions.convert('sr','mas',scale) 
 504   
 505  Subsection 4.2. Seismic constraints 
 506  ----------------------------------- 
 507   
 508  If the star shows clear solar-like oscillations, you can use the nu_max give an 
 509  independent constraint on the surface gravity, given the effective temperature of 
 510  the model (you are free to give errors or not, just keep in mind that in the 
 511  former case, you will get an array of Uncertainties rather than floats):: 
 512       
 513      >> teff = 4260.,'K' 
 514      >> nu_max = 38.90,0.86,'muHz' 
 515      >> logg_slo = conversions.derive_logg_slo(teff,nu_max,unit='[cm/s2']) 
 516   
 517  If you have the large separation (l=0 modes) and the nu_max, you can get an 
 518  estimate of the radius:: 
 519   
 520      >> Deltanu0 = 4.80,0.02,'muHz' 
 521      >> R_slo = conversions.derive_radius_slo(numax,Deltanu0,teff,unit='Rsol') 
 522       
 523  Then from the radius, you can get both the absolute luminosity and distance to 
 524  your star. 
 525   
 526  Subsection 4.3. Parallaxes 
 527  -------------------------- 
 528   
 529  From the parallax, you can get an estimate of the distance. This is, however, 
 530  dependent on some prior assumptions such as the shape of the galaxy and the 
 531  distribution of stars. To estimate the probability density value due to 
 532  a measured parallax of a star at particular distance, you can call L{distance.distprob}:: 
 533       
 534      >> gal_latitude = 0.5 
 535      >> plx = 3.14,0.5 
 536      >> d_prob = distance.distprob(d,gal_latitude,plx) 
 537   
 538  Using this distance, you can get an estimate for the radius of your star, and 
 539  thus also the absolute luminosity. 
 540   
 541  Subsection 4.4: Reddening constraints 
 542  ------------------------------------- 
 543   
 544  An estimate of the reddening of a star at a particular distance may be obtained 
 545  with the L{extinctionmodels.findext} function. There are currently three 
 546  reddening maps available: Drimmel, Marshall and Arenou:: 
 547   
 548      >> lng,lat = 120.,-0.5 
 549      >> dist = 100. # pc 
 550      >> Rv = 3.1 
 551      >> EBV = extinctionmodels.findext(lng,lat,model='drimmel',distance=dist)/Rv 
 552      >> EBV = extinctionmodels.findext(lng,lat,model='marshall',distance=dist)/Rv 
 553      >> EBV = extinctionmodels.findext(lng,lat,model='arenou',distance=dist)/Rv 
 554   
 555

 608      """ 
 609      Clean/extend/fix record array received from C{get_photometry}. 
 610       
 611      This function does a couple of things: 
 612       
 613          1. Adds common but uncatalogized colors like 2MASS.J-H if not already 
 614             present. WARNING: these colors can mix values from the same system 
 615             but from different catalogs! 
 616          2. Removes photometry for which no calibration is available 
 617          3. Adds a column 'color' with flag False denoting absolute flux measurement 
 618          and True denoting color. 
 619          4. Adds a column 'include' with flag True meaning the value will be 
 620          included in the fit 
 621          5. Sets some default errors to photometric values, for which we know 
 622          that the catalog values are not trustworthy. 
 623          6. Sets a lower limit to the allowed errors of 1%. Errors below this 
 624          value are untrostworthy because the calibration error is larger than that. 
 625          7. USNOB1 and ANS photometry are set the have a minimum error of 30% 
 626          due to uncertainties in response curves. 
 627       
 628      @param master: record array containing photometry. This should have the fields 
 629      'meas','e_meas','unit','photband','source','_r','_RAJ2000','DEJ2000', 
 630      'cmeas','e_cmeas','cwave','cunit' 
 631      @type master: record array 
 632      @param e_default: default error for measurements without errors 
 633      @type e_default: float 
 634      @return: record array extended with fields 'include' and 'color', and with 
 635      rows added (see above description) 
 636      @rtype: numpy recard array 
 637      """ 
 638      #-- we recognize uncalibrated stuff as those for which no absolute flux was 
 639      #   obtained, and remove them: 
 640      master = master[-np.isnan(master['cmeas'])] 
 641      cats = np.array([ph.split('.')[0] for ph in master['source']]) 
 642      set_cats = sorted(set(cats)) 
 643      #-- add common uncatalogized colors: 
 644      columns = list(master.dtype.names) 
 645      #-- if the separate bands are available (and not the color itself), 
 646      #   calculate the colors here. We need to do this for every separate 
 647      #   system! 
 648      add_rows = [] 
 649      for cat in set_cats: 
 650          master_ = master[cats==cat] 
 651       
 652          for color in ['2MASS.J-H','2MASS.KS-H','TD1.1565-1965','TD1.2365-1965','TD1.2365-2740', 
 653                    'JOHNSON.J-H','JOHNSON.K-H','JOHNSON.B-V','JOHNSON.U-B','JOHNSON.R-V','JOHNSON.I-V', 
 654                    'GALEX.FUV-NUV','TYCHO2.BT-VT','WISE.W1-W2','WISE.W3-W2','WISE.W4-W3', 
 655                    'SDSS.U-G','SDSS.G-R','SDSS.R-I','SDSS.R-Z', 
 656                    'UVEX.U-G','UVEX.G-R','UVEX.R-I','UVEX.HA-I', 
 657                    'DENIS.I-J','DENIS.KS-J', 
 658                    'ANS.15N-15W','ANS.15W-18','ANS.18-22','ANS.22-25','ANS.25-33']: 
 659              #-- get the filter system and the separate bands for these colors 
 660              system,band = color.split('.') 
 661              band0,band1 = band.split('-') 
 662              band0,band1 = '%s.%s'%(system,band0),'%s.%s'%(system,band1) 
 663           
 664              if band0 in master_['photband'] and band1 in master_['photband'] and not color in master_['photband']: 
 665                  #-- where are the bands located? 
 666                  index0 = list(master_['photband']).index(band0) 
 667                  index1 = list(master_['photband']).index(band1) 
 668                   
 669                  #-- start a new row to add the color 
 670                  row = list(master_[index1]) 
 671                  row[columns.index('photband')] = color 
 672                  row[columns.index('cwave')] = np.nan 
 673                   
 674                  #-- it could be a magnitude difference 
 675                  if master_['unit'][index0]=='mag': 
 676                      row[columns.index('meas')] = master_['meas'][index0]-master_['meas'][index1] 
 677                      row[columns.index('e_meas')] = np.sqrt(master_['e_meas'][index0]**2+master_['e_meas'][index1]**2) 
 678                      #-- error will not always be available... 
 679                      try: 
 680                          row[columns.index('cmeas')],row[columns.index('e_cmeas')] = conversions.convert('mag_color','flux_ratio',row[columns.index('meas')],row[columns.index('e_meas')],photband=color) 
 681                      except AssertionError: 
 682                          row[columns.index('cmeas')] = conversions.convert('mag_color','flux_ratio',row[columns.index('meas')],photband=color) 
 683                          row[columns.index('e_cmeas')] = np.nan 
 684                  #-- or it could be a flux ratio 
 685                  else: 
 686                      row[columns.index('meas')] = master_['meas'][index0]/master_['meas'][index1] 
 687                      row[columns.index('e_meas')] = np.sqrt(((master_['e_meas'][index0]/master_['meas'][index0])**2+(master_['e_meas'][index1]/master_['meas'][index1])**2)*row[columns.index('meas')]**2) 
 688                      row[columns.index('cmeas')],row[columns.index('e_cmeas')] = row[columns.index('meas')],row[columns.index('e_meas')] 
 689                  row[columns.index('cunit')] = 'flux_ratio'

 697      if not 'color' in master.dtype.names:

 702      else:

 705      #-- set default errors if no errors are available and set really really

 709          master['e_cmeas'][no_error] = np.abs(e_default*master['cmeas'][no_error])

 711          master['e_cmeas'][small_error] = 0.01*np.abs(master['cmeas'][small_error]) 
 712       
 713      #-- the measurements from USNOB1 are not that good because the response 
 714      #   curve is approximated by the JOHNSON filter. Set the errors to min 30% 
 715      #   The same holds for ANS: here, the transmission curves are very uncertain 
 716      for i,photband in enumerate(master['photband']): 
 717          if 'USNOB1' in photband or 'ANS' in photband: 
 718              master['e_cmeas'][i] = max(0.30*master['cmeas'][i],master['e_cmeas'][i]) 
 719       
 720      #-- remove negative fluxes 
 721      master = master[master['cmeas']>0] 
 722       
 723      return master

 727      """ 
 728      Exclude/include photometric passbands containing one of the strings listed in 
 729      photbands. 
 730       
 731      This function will set the flags in the 'include' field of the extended 
 732      master record array. 
 733       
 734      Colours also have a wavelength in this function, and it is defined as the 
 735      average wavelength of the included bands (doesn't work for stromgren C1 and M1). 
 736       
 737      include=False excludes photometry based on the input parameters. 
 738      include=True includes photometry based on the input parameters. 
 739       
 740      Some examples: 
 741       
 742          1. Exclude all measurements:: 
 743           
 744          >> decide_phot(master,wrange=(-np.inf,+np.inf),ptype='all',include=False) 
 745       
 746          2. Include all TD1 fluxes and colors:: 
 747           
 748          >> decide_phot(master,names=['TD1'],ptype='all',include=True) 
 749       
 750          3. Include all V band measurements from all systems (but not the colors):: 
 751           
 752          >> decide_phot(master,names=['.V'],ptype='abs',include=True) 
 753       
 754          4. Include all Geneva colors and exclude Geneva magnitudes:: 
 755           
 756          >> decide_phot(master,names=['GENEVA'],ptype='col',include=True) 
 757          >> decide_phot(master,names=['GENEVA'],ptype='abs',include=False) 
 758       
 759          5. Exclude all infrared measurements beyond 1 micron:: 
 760           
 761          >> decide_phot(master,wrange=(1e4,np.inf),ptype='all',include=False) 
 762       
 763          6. Include all AKARI measurements below 10 micron:: 
 764           
 765          >> decide_phot(master,names=['AKARI'],wrange=(-np.inf,1e5),ptype='all',include=True) 
 766       
 767      @param master: record array containing all photometry 
 768      @type master: numpy record array 
 769      @param names: strings excerpts to match filters 
 770      @type names: list of strings 
 771      @param wrange: wavelength range (most likely angstrom) to include/exclude 
 772      @type wrange: 2-tuple (start wavelength,end wavelength) 
 773      @param sources: list of sources 
 774      @type sources: list of strings 
 775      @param indices: list of indices (integers) 
 776      @type indices: list of integers 
 777      @param ptype: type of photometry to include/exclude: absolute values, colors 
 778      or both 
 779      @type ptype: string, one of 'abs','col','all' 
 780      @param include: flag setting exclusion or inclusion 
 781      @type include: boolean 
 782      @return: master record array with adapted 'include' flags 
 783      @rtype: numpy record array 
 784      """  
 785      #-- exclude/include passbands based on their names 
 786      if names is not None: 
 787          logger.info('%s photometry based on photband containining one of %s'%((include and 'Include' or "Exclude"),names)) 
 788          for index,photband in enumerate(master['photband']): 
 789              for name in names: 
 790                  if name in photband: 
 791                      if ptype=='all' or (ptype=='abs' and -master['color'][index]) or (ptype=='col' and master['color'][index]): 
 792                          master['include'][index] = include 
 793                          break 
 794      #-- exclude/include colors based on their wavelength 
 795      if wrange is not None: 
 796          logger.info('%s photometry based on photband wavelength between %s'%((include and 'Include' or "Exclude"),wrange)) 
 797          for index,photband in enumerate(master['photband']): 
 798              system,color = photband.split('.') 
 799              if not '-' in color or ptype=='abs': 
 800                  continue 
 801              band0,band1 = color.split('-') 
 802              cwave0 = filters.eff_wave('%s.%s'%(system,band0)) 
 803              cwave1 = filters.eff_wave('%s.%s'%(system,band1)) 
 804              if (wrange[0]<cwave0<wrange[1]) or (wrange[0]<cwave0<wrange[1]): 
 805                  master['include'][index] = include 
 806          #-- exclude/include passbands based on their wavelength 
 807          if not ptype=='col': 
 808              master['include'][(wrange[0]<master['cwave']) & (master['cwave']<wrange[1])] = include     
 809      #-- exclude/include passbands based on their source 
 810      if sources is not None: 
 811          logger.info('%s photometry based on source catalog in %s'%((include and 'Include' or "Exclude"),sources)) 
 812          for index,msource in enumerate(master['source']): 
 813              for source in sources: 
 814                  if source==msource: 
 815                      if ptype=='all' or (ptype=='abs' and -master['color'][index]) or (ptype=='col' and master['color'][index]): 
 816                          master['include'][index] = include

1229              2. scheme = 'color': means including all colors, excluding all absolute values

1231              system (the one with the smallest relative error)

1237          """ 
1238          #-- only absolute values: real SED fitting 
1239          if 'abs' in scheme.lower(): 
1240              self.master['include'][self.master['color']] = False 
1241              self.master['include'][-self.master['color']] = True 
1242              logger.info('Fitting procedure will use only absolute fluxes (%d)'%(sum(self.master['include']))) 
1243          #-- only colors: color fitting 
1244          elif 'col' in scheme.lower(): 
1245              self.master['include'][self.master['color']] = True 
1246              self.master['include'][-self.master['color']] = False 
1247              logger.info('Fitting procedure will use only colors (%d)'%(sum(self.master['include']))) 
1248          #-- combination: all colors and one absolute value per system 
1249          elif 'com' in scheme.lower(): 
1250              self.master['include'][self.master['color'] & self.master['include']] = True 
1251              systems = np.array([photband.split('.')[0] for photband in self.master['photband']]) 
1252              set_systems = sorted(list(set(systems))) 
1253              for isys in set_systems: 
1254                  keep = -self.master['color'] & (isys==systems) & self.master['include'] 
1255                  if not sum(keep): continue 
1256                  index = np.argmax(self.master['e_cmeas'][keep]/self.master['cmeas'][keep]) 
1257                  index = np.arange(len(self.master))[keep][index] 
1258                  self.master['include'][keep] = False 
1259                  self.master['include'][index] = True 
1260              logger.info('Fitting procedure will use colors + one absolute flux for each system (%d)'%(sum(self.master['include']))) 
1261          #-- infrared flux method scheme 
1262          elif 'irfm' in scheme.lower(): 
1263              #-- check which measurements are in the infrared 
1264              for i,meas in enumerate(self.master): 
1265                  #-- if measurement is in the infrared and it is a color, remove it (only use absolute values in IR) 
1266                  #-- for colors, make sure *both* wavelengths are checked 
1267                  if meas['color']: 
1268                      bands = filters.get_color_photband(meas['photband']) 
1269                      eff_waves = filters.eff_wave(bands) 
1270                      is_infrared = any([(conversions.Unit(*infrared)<conversions.Unit(eff_wave,'AA')) for eff_wave in eff_waves]) 
1271                  else: 
1272                      is_infrared = conversions.Unit(*infrared)<conversions.Unit(meas['cwave'],'AA')

1276                  elif is_infrared:

1282                  elif not is_infrared:

1285              use_abs = sum(self.master['include'] & -self.master['color'])

1396           
1397          Parallax must be given in mas.

1400          be assumed.

1403          the distance, otherwise the distance is computed from simply inverting 
1404          the parallax.

1407

1409          @rtype: (float,float)

1417              raise ValueError('distance cannot be computed from parallax (no position)') 
1418          gal = self.info['galpos'] 
1419          #-- if the parallax has an uncertainty and the Lutz-Kelker bias needs 
1420          #   to be taken into account, compute probability density function

1426              return d,dprob 
1427          #-- just invert (with or without error) 
1428          else: 
1429              dist = (conversions.Unit(plx,'kpc-1')**-1).convert(unit) 
1430              logger.info('Computed distance to target via parallax inversion: {:s}'.format(dist))

1453 -    def compute_distance(self,mtype='igrid_search'): 

1454          """ 
1455          Compute distance from radius and angular diameter (scale factor). 
1456           
1457          The outcome is added to the C{results} attribute:: 
1458           
1459              distance = r/sqrt(scale) 
1460           
1461          This particularly useful when you added constraints from solar-like 
1462          oscillations (L{add_constraint_slo}). 
1463           
1464          @return: distance,uncertainty (pc) 
1465          @rtype: (float,float) 
1466          """ 
1467          grid = self.results[mtype]['grid'] 
1468          radius = grid['radius'] 
1469          e_radius = grid['e_radius'] 
1470          scale = grid['scale'] 
1471          e_scale = grid['escale'] 
1472           
1473          radius = conversions.unumpy.uarray([radius,e_radius]) 
1474          scale = conversions.unumpy.uarray([scale,e_scale]) 
1475           
1476          distance = radius/scale**0.5 
1477          distance = conversions.convert('Rsol','pc',distance) 
1478          distance,e_distance = conversions.unumpy.nominal_values(distance),\ 
1479                        conversions.unumpy.std_devs(distance) 
1480          self.results[mtype]['grid'] = pl.mlab.rec_append_fields(grid,\ 
1481                          ['distance','e_distance'],[distance,e_distance]) 
1482          d,e_d = distance.mean(),distance.std()  
1483          logger.info("Computed distance from R and scale: {0}+/-{1} pc".format(d,e_d)) 
1484          return d,e_d

2304 -    def add_constraint_reddening(self,distance=None,ebv=None,e_ebv=0.1,Rv=3.1,\ 
2305                  model=None,mtype='igrid_search',chi2_type='red',upper_limit=False): 

2306          """ 
2307          Use reddening maps to put additional constraints on the parameters. 
2308                   
2309          This constraint assumes that, if C{upper_limit=False}, given the 
2310          distance to target, the reddening from the reddening maps is similar to 
2311          the one derived from the SED. All models where this is not the case will 
2312          be deemed improbable. 
2313           
2314          If C{upper_limit=True}, all models with an E(B-V) value above C{ebv} 
2315          will be considered improbable. 
2316           
2317          When you don't set C{ebv}, the value will, by default, be derived from 
2318          Drimmel maps if C{upper_limit=False} and from Schlegel if 
2319          C{upper_limit=True}. You can change this behaviour by setting C{model} 
2320          manually. 
2321                   
2322          @param distance: distance and uncertainty in parsec 
2323          @type distance: tuple (float,float) 
2324          @param ebv: E(B-V) reddening in magnitude 
2325          @type ebv: float 
2326          @param e_ebv: error on the reddening in percentage 
2327          @type e_ebv: float 
2328          @param model: model reddening maps 
2329          @type model: str 
2330          @param mtype: type of results to add the information to 
2331          @type mtype: str 
2332          @param upper_limit: consider the E(B-V) value as an upper limit 
2333          @type upper_limit: bool 
2334          """ 
2335          #-- for upper limits on E(B-V), we best use Schlegel maps by default, 
2336          #   otherwise we best use Drimmel maps. 
2337          if model is None and upper_limit: 
2338              model = 'schlegel' 
2339          elif model is None: 
2340              model = 'drimmel' 
2341          #-- if I need to figure out the reddening myself, I need the distance! 
2342          if ebv is None and distance is None: 
2343              distance = self.get_distance_from_plx(lutz_kelker=False,unit='pc') 
2344          #-- let me figure out the reddening if you didn't give it: 
2345          if ebv is None: 
2346              gal = self.info['galpos'] 
2347              ebv = extinctionmodels.findext(gal[0], gal[1], model=model, distance=distance[0])/Rv 
2348              ebv_u = extinctionmodels.findext(gal[0], gal[1], model=model, distance=distance[0]-distance[1])/Rv 
2349              ebv_l = extinctionmodels.findext(gal[0], gal[1], model=model, distance=distance[0]+distance[1])/Rv 
2350              e_ebv = max(ebv-ebv_l,ebv_u-ebv) 
2351          else: 
2352              e_ebv = 0.1*ebv 
2353          grid = self.results[mtype]['grid'] 
2354          ebvs = grid['ebv'] 
2355          #-- probabilities are differently calculated depending on upper limit. 
2356          if not upper_limit: 
2357              ebv_prob = scipy.stats.distributions.norm.cdf(abs(ebv-ebvs)/e_ebv) 
2358              #-- combine p values using Fisher's method 
2359              combined_pvals = evaluate.fishers_method([1-grid['ci_'+chi2_type],ebv_prob]) 
2360              grid['ci_'+chi2_type] = 1-combined_pvals 
2361          else: 
2362              grid['ci_'+chi2_type] = np.where(ebvs<=ebv,grid['ci_'+chi2_type],1.) 
2363           
2364          #-- and replace the original confidence intervals, and re-order 
2365          sa = np.argsort(grid['ci_'+chi2_type])[::-1] 
2366          self.results[mtype]['grid'] = grid[sa] 
2367           
2368          #-- update the confidence intervals 
2369          self.calculate_confidence_intervals(mtype=mtype) 
2370          logger.info('Added constraint: E(B-V)={0}+/-{1}'.format(ebv,e_ebv))

2376          """ 
2377          Add constraints on the mass. 
2378           
2379          C{mass} must be a tuple, if the second element is smaller than the first, 
2380          it is assumed to be (mu,sigma) from a normal distribution. If the second 
2381          element is larger than the first, it is assumed to be (lower, upper) 
2382          from a uniform distribution. 
2383          """ 
2384          normal = mass[0]>mass[1] 
2385          grid = self.results[mtype]['grid'] 
2386          masses = grid['mass'] 
2387          if normal: 
2388              mass_prob = scipy.stats.distributions.norm.cdf(abs(mass[0]-masses)/mass[1]) 
2389              #-- combine p values using Fisher's method 
2390              combined_pvals = evaluate.fishers_method([1-grid['ci_'+chi2_type],mass_prob]) 
2391              grid['ci_'+chi2_type] = 1-combined_pvals 
2392          else: 
2393              grid['ci_'+chi2_type] = np.where((masses<=mass[0]) | (mass[1]<=masses),1.,grid['ci_'+chi2_type]) 
2394           
2395          #-- and replace the original confidence intervals, and re-order 
2396          sa = np.argsort(grid['ci_'+chi2_type])[::-1] 
2397          self.results[mtype]['grid'] = grid[sa] 
2398           
2399          #-- update the confidence intervals 
2400          self.calculate_confidence_intervals(mtype=mtype) 
2401          logger.info('Added constraint: mass={0}+/-{1}'.format(*mass))
